content:
thunderbird offers a preview page. That is the one that displays content without clicking the message to open in a larger view. If you click through messages by clicking the link in message list pane, you are in the preview screen. But I am assuming your question is on privacy. Some tips are here:

  1. to avoid sending return receipts, click settings>general and scroll down to the 'return receipts' button and set to not return them
  2. in settings>privacy&security, untick to allow remote content in messages (you can add exceptions for senders you trust)

Doing those two things helps prevent senders from being informed when you read a message.
creator: davidsk

content: If by preview, you mean the first few lines of a message without opening it, there is no such option in TB (or any other mail app). If you see any part of a message beyond the headers, the message has been opened to the same degree as if it has been deliberately 'opened'. The default privacy settings will block remote content, and TB doesn't run scripts in any opened message, so beside that you'll have to exercise your judgment as to whether the message is legitimate.
creator: sfhowes

content:
There is nothing in that log to indicate anything but a successful IMAP login followed by a timeout when the system is asked for mail.

My guess is you have a defective antivirus product.

If it was a router issue you would not authenticate. If it was an encryption TLS type issue, again you would not authenticate. The server is indication is has a "next mail" and provided the reference.

SO I am guessing the antivirus is intercepting the message and going off to la la land. So try disabling the mail scanner and see if that helps.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Thunderbird è un software gratuito per cui non esiste un supporto tecnico i cui costi sarebbero insostenibili. Questo è solo un forum di utenti volontari, chi vi partecipa lo fa con i tempi e modi che preferisce. Questo per dirti che arrivare qui, protendere riscontri urgenti e minacciare di cambiare software è del tutto surreale. Che tu usi o meno Thunderbird non cambia nulla per nessuno (se non per te stesso).

Seconda osservazione: probabile che tu sia abituato ad ecosistemi come quelli di Google, Apple e Microsoft dove la tua attività è strettamente monitorata e profilata. Ma Thunderbird non funziona così. Il programma opera completamente sotto il tuo controllo e tutti i suoi dati restano sul tuo PC. In altre parole se vuoi che qualcuno provi a darti una mano su questo forum devi riportare il maggior numero di dettagli possibili a cominciare dai messaggi di errore che ricevi quando provi a scaricare la posta con Thunderbird. Dire semplicemente che "non scarica la posta" è del tutto inutile proprio perché Thunderbird non è un servizio centralizzato ed il problema non è generale.
creator: @next

content:
This usually indicates a corrupted install. Try these steps:

  1. do NOT uninstall, as that may delete your message folders
  2. locate the program, either at c:\program files or c:\program files (x86) and delete it
  3. download and install your preferred version. I recommend ver 128, but it's your call.
  4. if you receive a compatibility error, locate the profile and delete a file named compatibility.ini (profile will be at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiless
creator: davidsk

creator: jennythpo

content:
Add your gmail, or other, account to TB so that Local Folders is created. Then, open the profile folder from Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Folder, close TB, copy the Takeout file to Mail/Local Folders, remove the .mbox extension, restart TB, find the folder under Local Folders in the Folder Pane.

Otherwise, search for a free mbox viewer.
creator: sfhowes
